title: Thinking of joining a nonprofit board in your retirement? You may be required to pony up your own money
text:
Many retirees serve on nonprofit boards. If you ask a roomful of them to rate their experience, some would rave about the joy of giving back. Others would call it a disaster.

Joining the board of directors of a nonprofit organization is a hit-or-miss proposition. But if you do your due diligence and follow a few simple rules at the outset, you’re more likely to come away satisfied.

“The nonprofit community always needs more board members,” said Cynthia Remec, executive director of New York City-based BoardAssist. “But if folks don’t approach the matching process thoughtfully, they won’t be happy with the board they join, which is a shame as there are more than enough boards that are great fits for most people.”

Avoid rushing your decision to join. Take it slowly and schedule multiple discussions with board members and senior staff.

“Treat it like a job interview,” said Andy Davis, director of education at BoardSource in Washington, D.C. “Clarify expectations and make sure you understand your obligations before you join.”

That’s better than agreeing to fill a board seat after an acquaintance approaches you. Perhaps the nonprofit seeks to tap your professional expertise—as an accountant, lawyer or marketing executive—and you figure you might as well share your knowledge.

Hit the pause button before you commit and ask questions such as:

• Am I passionate about the organization’s mission?

• Do I like the people (both board members and staff)?

• Who else is on the board?

• What am I expected to give (including straight-up cash, in-kind donations and buying tickets to pricey fundraisers)?

• To what extent am I expected to enlist others to give?

“You want to have the ‘give-get’ in writing—the amount you give and the amount you get from others each year,” Remec said. “Find out if the two numbers are interchangeable.” If the give-get is $5,000, for example, ask if you must personally donate a certain amount even if you raise $5,000 from others.

Remec adds that while many retirees who join boards are willing to give a certain amount each year to the nonprofit, they may feel uncomfortable soliciting their friends to donate. Others say, “If I’m on the board, I’ll make a donation but I want my primary gift to be my intellectual capital.”

Of course, your stint on the board should consist of more than giving money and getting money from others. It’s more rewarding when you can have a positive impact by, say, helping raise the organization’s profile or improving its operation.

Remec suggests asking for three examples of what board members have accomplished over the last year that didn’t involve raising capital. Perhaps the board helped redesign the nonprofit’s website, developed new bylaws or crafted a strategic plan. This gives you an idea of the board’s impact beyond money.

When meeting other board members and the organization’s executive director, are you inspired and impressed? You’ll be working closely with these individuals, so you want to feel a mix of admiration and camaraderie.

You also want to gauge whether you’ll make a difference. Remec warns that “the biggest reason a board match fails” is a newcomer feels devalued.

“The worst thing is to go on the board and then find that no one listens to you or cares what you say,” she said. “We hear people say, ‘They just wanted my money or for me to get money from other people.’”

Don’t forget the small stuff. Clarify up front where and when the board meets. If the time or location of these gatherings poses an inconvenience to you, ask if you can call in.

“If you can’t come to all the board meetings and you need to phone in, ask how many other board members do that,” Remec said. “You don’t want to be the only one who phones in.”

Finally, investigate the organization’s finances, recent history and key metrics such as employee turnover. If you’re joining a board of a nonprofit that just completed a merger or other major transition, gird for some conflict. Disruptive change rarely unfolds in a seamless, stress-free manner.

“Look at the organization’s Form 990 for the last couple of years,” said Rick Cohen, chief communications officer at the National Council of Nonprofits in Washington, D.C. “What direction is it going in terms of year-end asset balance? Did it lose money?”

You can usually find Form 990 online—it’s a public document filed with the IRS—or ask the nonprofit for a copy. While you’re at it, confirm that the organization carries Directors & Officers (D&O) insurance. In some cases, board members can be held personally liable for the actions of the nonprofit.
description: Read the fine print: It should be more than giving and getting money.
